marketNews.title: Average Minimum Wage Increase +6.5% in 2025
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto announced that the average increase in the minimum wage for 2025 will be +6.5%. In general, this increase is in line with the upper bound estimate we previously wrote in Stockbit Snips, which implies a larger alpha variable. However, the government has not yet released the regulation regarding the formula used to calculate the minimum wage increase. Labour Minister Yassierli said that the new ministerial regulation on the minimum wage will be released on Wednesday (4/12). The regulation will replace Government Regulation No. 51/2023 on wages, which was annulled by the Constitutional Court in October 2024 after the labour cluster was removed from the Omnibus Law. Yassierli hopes that regional governments can quickly release adjustment rules for their respective regions, with the target that provincial minimum wages (UMP) and district/city minimum wages (UMK) for 2025 can be announced before Christmas 2024. Following the news of the minimum wage increase, the Chairman of the Indonesian Employers Association, Shinta Kamdani, assessed the +6.5% adjustment as too large, potentially triggering layoffs and hindering new job creation. On the other hand, the Chairman of the Indonesian Labour Union (KSPI) and the Labour Party, Said Iqbal, said that workers will cancel the planned national strike because an agreement on the minimum wage increase has been reached. Realisation of the minimum wage increase at the regional level can deviate from the central government’s set increase. The detailed breakdown is shown in the accompanying chart. Key Takeaway: The +6.5% figure will become a reference for each region. Compared with the average realised increase across all Indonesian regions in recent years, the increase is higher than in 2024 and is relatively high over the past three years, although not as high as in 2023.

marketNews.title: BPS reports Consumer Price Index inflation 1.55% YoY in November 2024
marketNews.content: BPS recorded that the consumer price index (CPI) inflation in Indonesia fell to 1.55% year‑on‑year in November 2024 (versus 1.71% YoY in October 2024), marking the lowest level since July 2021 although it slightly missed the consensus expectation of 1.5% YoY. On a monthly basis, CPI inflation rose to 0.3% month‑on‑month (versus 0.08% MoM in October 2024), surpassing the consensus of 0.26% MoM and representing the fastest monthly increase in eight months. The monthly rise was driven by food, beverages and tobacco (contributing 0.22 percentage points) and jewellery gold (contributing 0.04 percentage points). Core inflation reached a 16‑month high of 2.26% YoY (versus 2.21% YoY in October 2024), above the consensus of 2.2% YoY.

marketNews.title: S&P Global reports Indonesia Manufacturing PMI 49.6 in November 2024
marketNews.content: S&P Global recorded that Indonesia's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 49.6 in November 2024 (versus 49.2 in October 2024), indicating a contraction in factory activity for the fifth consecutive month but representing the strongest reading in that period. S&P Global's Economic Director Paul Smith said the November PMI was mixed, with output growing for the first time in five months while sales continued to decline for the fifth month. This led to the fastest employment decline in three years. Meanwhile, confidence in the outlook improved to a nine‑month high, with companies expecting higher demand and new orders in the coming year.

marketNews.title: S&P Global reports China Manufacturing PMI 51.5 in November 2024
marketNews.content: S&P Global recorded that China's manufacturing PMI rose to 51.5 in November 2024 (versus 50.3 in October 2024), surpassing the consensus level of 50.5. The result marks an expansion of factory activity for the second consecutive month and the fastest growth since June 2024. The increase was driven by the strongest foreign order growth since February 2023 and higher exports. Output also reached its highest level in five months.

marketNews.title: President Prabowo announces free nutritious meal allocation 10,000 IDR per portion
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto announced that the allocation for the free nutritious meal program will be 10,000 rupiah per portion, lower than the previously discussed level of 15,000 rupiah per portion. The head of the National Nutrition Agency, Dadan Hindayana, said that the budget for the program in the 2025 state budget is still calculated at 15,000 rupiah per portion. However, implementation will be flexible, adjusting to local food price levels, with possible cross‑regional subsidies. In the 2025 state budget, the free lunch program budget reaches 71 trillion rupiah, targeting about 19.47 million beneficiaries ranging from school children to pregnant and nursing mothers.

marketNews.title: US President Donald Trump threatens 100% tariff on BRICS members
marketNews.content: US President Donald Trump said he will impose a 100% tariff on BRICS member countries if the bloc acts to weaken the US dollar. The BRICS group consists of Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates. Indonesia has been a partner (not a full member) of BRICS since October 2024, and the Foreign Minister, Sugiono, said Indonesia wants to join the group because it is a suitable vehicle to advance the interests of developing countries.

marketNews.title: President‑elect Prabowo's advisor Hashim Djojohadikusumo says new Ministry of State Revenue will be formed
marketNews.content: Hashim Djojohadikusumo, advisor and younger brother of President‑elect Prabowo Subianto, said the government plans to establish a Ministry of State Revenue to increase state income. The new ministry will manage state revenue, including taxes, excise and mining royalties. Hashim mentioned that President Prabowo will appoint Deputy Finance Minister Anggito Abimanyu to lead the new ministry, but did not specify when it will be formed.

marketNews.title: BPS reports foreign tourist arrivals 1.2 million in October 2024
marketNews.content: BPS recorded that foreign tourist arrivals (wisman) to Indonesia reached approximately 1.2 million in October 2024, a decline of 6.7% month‑on‑month but an increase of 22% year‑on‑year. During the first ten months of 2024, foreign tourist arrivals rose 20.5% YoY to about 11.6 million, representing 82.9% of the government's 2024 target of 14 million.

tickerNews.title: Higher minimum wage may boost consumer stocks $ICBP and $MYOR and pressure high‑opex stocks $ACES and $MAPI
tickerNews.content: The higher minimum wage increase is likely to raise purchasing power and have a positive impact on consumer issuers such as $ICBP and $MYOR. On the other hand, the increase may compress profitability for issuers with a high proportion of employee wages in operating expenses, such as $ACES and $MAPI.

tickerNews.title: $BRMS reports net profit of $6.7 million in 3Q24 and $15.7 million for 9M24
tickerNews.content: $BRMS: Bumi Resources Minerals recorded net profit of $6.7 million (+24.5% QoQ, +36% YoY) in 3Q24. This result brings net profit for the first nine months of 2024 to $15.7 million (+49.3% YoY), surpassing our estimate at 79.3% of the Stockbit FY24F estimate. Operationally, revenue and operating profit for 9M24 reached $108.5 million (+231% YoY) and $28.6 million (+189% YoY), representing 112% and 108% of the Stockbit FY24F estimate. The outperformance was mainly driven by gold production volume of 45,366 troy ounces (+176% YoY), 109% of the Stockbit FY24F estimate.

tickerNews.title: $BUMI reports net profit of $43 million in 3Q24 and $123 million for 9M24
tickerNews.content: $BUMI: Bumi Resources recorded net profit of $43 million (+120% QoQ) in 3Q24, reversing a net loss of $24 million in 3Q23. This result brings BUMI's net profit for the first nine months of 2024 to $123 million (+111% YoY). Operationally, operating profit in 3Q24 grew +663% QoQ, supported by revenue growth of +16.2% QoQ. Meanwhile, cost of goods sold grew more modestly (+15% QoQ), and operating expenses fell -10.5% QoQ.

tickerNews.title: $BNGA reports October 2024 net profit of 430 billion rupiah
tickerNews.content: $BNGA: Bank CIMB Niaga reported net profit (bank only) of 430 billion rupiah (+3.5% YoY, -31% MoM) in October 2024, resulting in a net profit (bank only) for the first ten months of 2024 of 5.4 trillion rupiah (+5.6% YoY). Net profit was pressured by non‑operational expenses of 212 billion rupiah in October 2024 (vs. October 2023: profit of 4.8 billion rupiah, September 2024: profit of 218 billion rupiah). Operating profit in October 2024 grew +34% YoY and +22% MoM, leading to operating profit for 10M24 up +4.8% YoY. Provision expenses eased, with credit cost in October 2024 falling to 0.44% (-23 bps YoY, -75 bps MoM) and credit cost for 10M24 at 0.66% (-30 bps YoY). Credit growth (including sharia financing) for 10M24 rose +5.6% YoY, in line with FY24 management guidance of +5‑7%. Net interest margin (NIM) in October 2024 slipped slightly to 3.69% (-26 bps YoY, -2 bps MoM), resulting in a 10M24 NIM of 3.85% (-34 bps YoY).

tickerNews.title: $BBTN plans to issue bonds up to 15 trillion rupiah in 2025 to support housing liquidity facilities
tickerNews.content: $BBTN: The President Director of Bank Tabungan Negara, Nixon L. P. Napitupulu, said the bank plans to issue bonds amounting to around 10‑15 trillion rupiah in 2025 to meet liquidity needs for the expanding quota of the Housing Liquidity Facility (FLPP). Nixon also mentioned that the government intends to raise the FLPP quota from 220,000 units in 2024 to 800,000 housing units in 2025, requiring an estimated budget of 80 trillion rupiah. However, FLPP is not solely implemented by BBTN.

tickerNews.title: $MBMA plans private placement of up to 10.8 billion rupiah (10% of shares) with 9.1% dilution
tickerNews.content: $MBMA: Merdeka Battery Materials plans to conduct a private placement of up to approximately 10.8 billion rupiah (10% of shares) resulting in a dilution of up to 9.1%. The prospective investors and execution price have not been disclosed, and the proceeds will be used for business development and working capital. The plan will be discussed at the Extraordinary General Meeting of Shareholders on 6 December 2024.

tickerNews.title: $MDKA plans to issue ~1 trillion rupiah bonds to fund subsidiary debt repayment and working capital
tickerNews.content: $MDKA: Merdeka Copper Gold intends to issue bonds worth approximately 1 trillion rupiah, with the proceeds to be loaned to its subsidiary PT Bumi Suksesindo for accelerated repayment of bank debt and working capital. The bond issue consists of Series A (367‑day tenor) and Series B (3‑year tenor); principal amounts and interest rates have not been disclosed. The public offering is expected on 18‑19 December 2024. The bonds have received a idA+ rating from Pefindo.

tickerNews.title: $BTPN plans to issue ~1.4 trillion rupiah bonds for business growth and credit provision
tickerNews.content: $BTPN: Bank SMBC Indonesia plans to issue bonds totaling approximately 1.4 trillion rupiah, with the proceeds intended for business expansion through credit provision. The bond issue comprises Series A of about 430 billion rupiah (6.7% interest, 3‑year tenor) and Series B of about 967 billion rupiah (6.95% interest, 5‑year tenor). The public offering is expected on 11‑12 December 2024. The bonds have received an idAAA rating from Pefindo.

tickerNews.title: $BBTN needs at least 150 trillion rupiah to finance 3 million houses per year
tickerNews.content: Deputy Minister of State‑Owned Enterprises, Kartika Wirjoatmodjo, said that Bank Tabungan Negara ($BBTN) requires at least 150 trillion rupiah to finance a program of building three million houses per year. She explained that this amount cannot be covered solely by third‑party funds, necessitating special financing such as bonds with tenors up to 15 years guaranteed by the government or foreign funding. She also mentioned possible schemes using the old‑age security (JHT) balances in BPJS Ketenagakerjaan as down‑payment and raising funds in the capital market.
